ICE-FISHING If you drive north from Toronto for three hours you come to Lake Nipissing. In winter the lake becomes ice and thousands of Canadian fishermen travel there each weekend. They build little houses of wood on the ice and paint them in bright colours. Then they sit inside to catch the fish that swim under the ice. The ice is so thick people can walk across the lake.

Ice-fishing in Canada is like summer holidays for the Canadian fisherman. It is also the best opportunity for the local people to work. When the lake freezes in January, the businessmen in town, who sell supplies to the fishermen, have a good few months of business. Restaurants and hotels do very well, and there are even ice-fishing contests in the towns near the lake.

In the summer, many people visit Nipissing, the fishing capital of Canada. They sit in their boats or fish from the shore. There are guides, stores, and restaurants.

The fishing here is world-class and some of the lakes are more than 200km2. However, the lake is most famous for its walleye, a type of fish that everyone enjoys eating. In the winter the walleye move deeper into the lake, so it is best to go ice fishing.

However, the ice fishing season is not very long. From January to March fishermen can catch walleye, pike, and trout in the icy water. To catch the fish, they use an auger which is like a special saw which cuts a hole in the ice. Through this hole, the fishermen drop a piece of fishing line called a jig, with a small bright coloured lure attached to it.

The most prestigious races in American horse racing are the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes. The Kentucky Derby, held in Louisville, Kentucky every year since 1875, is known as "The Run for the Roses" and is considered by many to be the greatest two minutes in sports. The Preakness Stakes, held near Baltimore in Maryland since 1873, is the second leg of the Triple Crown Series and traditionally comes second in the order of races. Grasses are classified as monocotyledons, having one seed leaf that emerges when the seed germinates. They have long, slender leaves growing from a basal rosette that forms a circle around the stem. The roots go down only about 4 inches and then shoot out, forming a mat that helps keep the soil from eroding.

3. How do grasses reproduce?
Grasses reproduce both by seed and vegetatively. They have a short life cycle of 1-5 years.

4. How does grass grow?
Grass grows from the base. They don't have flowers, but they produce flowers in the tops of the plants. They do this because it is easier to spread seeds this way. Seeds are spread by wind and animals.

Grass is mainly used as pasture for livestock and for making hay. Grass can be cut and dried or left to wilt and dry naturally.

The Albuquerque Balloon Festival Every autumn the sky above the desert city of Albuquerque in the south-western United States turns into a mass of bright colours. This is the Albuquerque Balloon festival an annual nine-day event. The first festival was held in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of the local radio station. The first festival was so popular with residents and tourists that it turned into an annual event.

It is now one of the largest balloon festivals in the world. The event takes place in mid-October and features over 500 hot air balloons of various shapes and sizes which fill the skies over the city for around 90 minutes before sunrise. At this time of day, the conditions are perfect for flying, as there is usually little wind and a cool temperature. The festival is not only about ballooning; it also has plenty of music, food, drink, entertainment and other attractions.

There are also various contests and competitions which pilots take part in, including distance and accuracy contests and ‘the Dawn Patrol’ (where pilots try to hit targets using the glow of their lit balloons). The event also sees many special shaped balloons in the sky, including a balloon which looks like an animal, a camel, or another shaped to look like a famous character, for example, Bugs Bunny and Homer Simpson.

The festival has been held for over 40 years, drawing visitors from all over the world. In 2002 it was voted ‘Best Outdoor Festival’ in the US by USA Today readers. The festival not only provides a spectacle of beautiful and unique hot air balloons but also raises a substantial amount of money for charity every year.

THE ROCKIES The Rocky Mountains run almost the length of North America. They start in the North-west but lie only a few hundred miles from the centre in more southern areas. Although the Rockies are smaller than the Alps they are no less wonderful. There are many roads across the Rockies but the best way to see them is to travel by train. The most famous of these railways is probably the Canadian Pacific Railway. This railway was built in the 1880s to join Canada's Atlantic and Pacific coasts. At that time the Rockies were still wild, uninhabited mountains. Today the railroad winds through forests, across bridges, and over valleys, passing through the great parks of Banff and Jasper. The Rockies are known for their unpredictable weather. The clouds can move quickly and snow can fall at any time of year.

- Where does the railway pass through?

THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST Hypatia was born in Alexandria in Egypt in 370 A.D. For many centuries she was the only woman scientist to have a place in the history books. Hypatia's father was director of Alexandria University and he made sure his daughter had the best education available. This was unusual as most women then had few opportunities to study. Hypatia herself studied mathematics, astronomy and philosophy and became the world's first female Professor of Mathematics at the Neo-Platonist school in Alexandria. It's said that the Neo-Platonist philosophy that Hypatia taught was a mix of Plato's ideas on philosophy and Pythagoras's work on mathematics. Hypatia was a brilliant teacher and many students came from near and far to learn from her. She was also highly respected for her wisdom and was often consulted by the authorities in Alexandria on various matters. Hypatia was eventually murdered by a mob of Christian fanatics in 415 A.D. This happened in a church where she had gone for her safety. Although she was not a Christian, she was considered a heretic by the Christian fanatics. Hypatia was buried in Alexandria but her works were destroyed by the mob. The ancient world, and Alexandria in particular, was a center of science and scholarship, and Hypatia was an important figure in this world. Her story is told in the book The Woman Who Lost her Head by Charles Kingsley.

No Title The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six" says Margaret Porter a violinist and music teacher. "It's the time when you are learning about the world." Margaret who lives in London prefers to take pupils at three and four although she has made lots of exceptions for keen five-year-olds.

Around the age of three children usually have enough coordination, concentration and listening skills to learn the violin. By the age of four children will be able to understand what they are being taught. By the age of five children's attention may not be as good as adults so extra effort may be needed to keep them focused.

Violins are not a toy and should never be treated as such. It's important to start learning violin at the right age so the child can learn properly. It's important to show them how to treat the instrument correctly. "Violins are expensive and there is so much to learn about playing one" Margaret continues "We must take care of our instruments and take our lessons seriously" she says.

Margaret is a good teacher and takes her job seriously, she can understand why some parents might wish to wait before they pay for lessons, "Sometimes I'll take children on a trial basis to see how they cope." she continues "But I still think three to six is the best age."

It's the children who have parents and/or grandparents who play instruments themselves who usually start earlier, they are given a violin as a present and are naturally very excited to play along with the adults.

Children who start too young may have difficulty grasping the concepts of music and stringed instruments. They may not have the necessary motor skills required to learn a musical instrument

SAMUEL PEPYS The most famous diary in English was written by Samuel Pepys. It gives a detailed and interesting description of everyday life in England between 1660 and 1669. Pepys writes about important news stories of the time like disease an enemy navy sailing up the River Thames and the Great Fire of London. He also writes about less important daily things like what he ate and what he saw.

Here is the entry for Tuesday 2nd September 1666, which describes a busy day during the Great Fire of London: "This morning, about a quarter before eight, I was called, and found the house all burning, and a great fire in the King’s house, near to us, that we were in some danger. The History of Shoes In the past importance was not given to shoes being comfortable or fashionable. These early foot coverings were probably animal skins which people tied round their ankles during cold weather. We still use leather today but other materials such as silk plastic or cotton are also popular depending on what is in fashion.

The 1st pair of high heeled shoes was created in China during the 13th century and only worn by the Emperor. The high heel had a practical use for horse riding, which enabled the wearer to stay in the stirrup if their foot slipped through the stirrup. The high heel shoes are very expensive as they are hand made and only produced by a few people who still have this skill.

In the 19th century rubber was introduced which meant shoes could have elastic laces and soles which were not leather. Today’s modern trainers (or sneakers in America) were invented in 1892 by an American man named William R. Johnson. He made them out of Kangaroo leather and rubber for the soles. This material gave them their cushioned feel.

Throughout history, shoe styles have changed dramatically but their basic function remains the same – to protect and support the foot from the ground. The ancient Egyptians considered shoes to be a status symbol and only royalty wore them. It wasn’t until the 18th century when footwear became widely available and affordable.

The Roman army required their soldiers to wear shoes made of leather, while the Greeks wore sandals for most occasions.

The Red Service cabins are more basic and affordable, offering good value. Both services provide air-conditioned comfort and a restaurant car for dining.

### Route of The Ghan

The journey begins in the Northern Territory capital of Darwin, then heads south to Katherine and Alice Springs in the heart of the Australian Outback. From there the Ghan heads southwards across the deserts of South Australia, and after a run along the coast it finally reaches its southern terminus of Adelaide.

ZOOS People began to keep animals in zoos over 3000 years ago when the rulers of China opened an enormous zoo called the Gardens of Intelligence. France has one of the oldest zoos in Europe, the Jardin des Plantes, which was established in 1793. One of the oldest zoos in the world is the Tiergarten Schoenenberg in Vienna, which was established in 1752. The largest zoo in the world is the Beijing Zoo in China, which has an area of 860 hectares and houses over 5000 animals. The second largest zoo in the world is the Phoenix Park Zoo in Dublin, Ireland. Some people think that zoos can help to protect and conserve endangered species, whereas others believe that the animals should be in the wild.

A five pound note may buy a book a huge bag of sweets or a couple of cinema tickets. But if there were a shortage of pound notes, the price would go up, and the number of things you could buy for that money would go down. The same is true for a country as a whole. If a country makes more things than people in that country or people in other countries want to buy. It can use this 'surplus' of goods to buy goods and services from other countries that want to buy more than the things they make. If, however, a country makes fewer things than people want to buy it is said to have a 'deficit' of goods.

### Money and Deficit

As a country with a deficit in the balance of payments, it will have to import goods and services to make up the shortfall. This is usually paid for with a shortage of money or by taking on debt. In the past, when countries had a large deficit of goods and services, they often used gold to 'pay the bill'. But since the Second World War countries have relied on money and debt to pay for these imports. This is how countries like the UK and the US have been able to acquire goods from around the world that they couldn't make themselves.

Interview Tips First impressions are often lasting ones. Studies show that people form impressions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They observe how we dress our eye contact our body movement and how fast or slowly we talk our volume and tone of voice as well as our our actual words. The most important of these factors, however, is how we make others feel about themselves. Make people feel at ease and good about themselves, and they will like you. The opposite is equally true. If we make them uncomfortable, or if we make them feel bad about themselves, they will not like us. The best way to make others feel good is to show a genuine interest in them. Learn the names of their children and the names of their company. If they say they just came from France or they just finished running a marathon, ask them about it. If someone wears a watch with a University logo, ask about their College experience. Ask others about what they do and how they got into it. Listen and respond to what they have to say. When you ask others about themselves, remember to focus on them, rather than on yourself. When someone asks you where you work or went to school, keep your answer short and polite. You want them to talk about themselves.

Going up the wall  Once climbers went to the mountains. Now a challenging climb can be had anywhere indoors or out. The crowd holds its breath. High above them on the climbing wall hanging upside down by the tips of two fingers is the French climber Francois Lombard. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at Birmingham's National Indoor Arena. "It is a mental battle," he says. "You must be focused and determined. You have to overcome your fear." "I always want to do a little better. I don't want to just finish in the same position that I did last year." Lombard finished third in his previous contest. He is hoping for a medal this time.

Practicing the skill  Indoor climbing is both popular and practical. "One of the things that has happened in recent years," says Mark Simmonds of the British Mountaineering Council, "is that more and more people are getting into climbing." While the popularity of indoor climbing has soared, the number of traditional outdoor climbers has remained virtually constant. "And you don't need a great deal of equipment to get started in indoor climbing," adds Simmonds. "You don't need any experience either. All you need is a pair of climbing shoes and a safety harness." And that is why many climbing organizations are encouraging indoor climbing. Many more people can be introduced to the sport under supervision. "The supervision is also a way of keeping climbing out of the courts, " says British Mountaineering Council chairman Bill Birkett. "With the right training, indoor climbing can be extremely safe."

An eye for detail Artist Susan Shepherd is best known for her flower paintings and the large garden that surrounds her house is the source of many of her subjects. It is full of her favourite flowers most especially varieties of tulips and poppies. Some of the plants are unruly and seed themselves all over the garden.

Susan Shepherd was born in London in 1947 and has always had an affinity with flowers. After completing a three year foundation course at Chelsea School of Art, she spent a year at the Central School of Art and Design where she studied printing. On a trip to India, she discovered the art of miniature painting which greatly influenced her later work.

After returning from India, she painted a lot of detailed botanical images. During the 1970s and 80s, she became well-known for her detailed oil paintings of flowers. Her work is full of intricate details, giving the flowers a life-like quality. The influence of Indian painting is still visible in the way she paints her flowers. They are often set against a dark background, which makes the detailed blossoms shine like jewels.

In addition to painting, Susan Shepherd has also worked as a printmaker, producing etchings and monoprints. She has been a visiting lecturer at many universities and currently teaches painting at City and Guilds of London Art School.

Susan Shepherd’s work can be found in the Royal Botanic Gardens at Kew and in private collections around the world. Her passion and respect for flowers comes through in her paintings, which capture the essence of the fragile beauty of the botanical world.

There was new furniture and Paul had a teacher. He was really going to Eton his father's school in the following autumn. Paul was over the moon at being accepted into the most prestigious school in the world. Paul's life now had a meaning. In this world and beyond, his uncle would be remembered as a good man for sending his godson to the most prestigious school in the world, Eton. His life was going to go on a new path. The next day Paul woke up early, full of energy and eagerness. He ran to his father's study and found his old suitcase. He put his old clothes inside. His suitcase was small, but it had a capacity of a thousand pieces of chocolate, that would be enough. Paul knew that whatever happened, he would always have what he loved. His old clothes were now like a talisman of his godfather. He took them from his suitcase and wore them. Paul left his house at last, in a very high spirit. He was really looking forward to getting to Eton in the fall.

This was the end of Uncle Oscar's journey but not the end of Paul's. The legacy of Uncle Oscar's sacrifice and generosity, will live on through the years, and beyond his grandchildren and great grandchildren. The love that Paul shared with his godfather, will forever be remembered. And for that we can be grateful.

In the Victorian era, outdoor skating became popular and people would travel on the train from London to Brighton to go ice skating on the frozen ponds.

The first recorded use of steel blades dates back to the 15th Century. Iron skates were being manufactured in Switzerland and Germany by the 16th century. The first recorded ice hockey game was played on January 31, 1853. Skate design has changed little over the years. The key technological developments include the addition of wheels, the introduction of steel blades, and the addition of wheels to the bottom of the skates. We are literally drowning in news. Have you ever tried reading the whole newspaper including the financial and sports pages? Or have you followed every piece of news on the front page of a news website? It's practically impossible. Reuters alone puts out 3.5 million news stories a year. And that's just one source.

So how do you decide which news is important and which isn't? You need to establish criteria for determining what is worth your time and what isn't.

First of all, consider your interests. You might be very interested in news about your own country, but might not care at all about news from another continent. Similarly, you might be passionate about sports, but don't really care about the latest movie releases.

Secondly, how recent is the news? News loses relevance very quickly. Today's big headline is usually yesterday's forgotten story. Therefore, pay attention to older news that is still relevant and important to you.

Thirdly, consider the source of the news. How reliable is it? Does it come from a reputable news outlet, such as the BBC or Al Jazeera, or is it a clickbait website that just wants to generate advertising revenue with sensational headlines? It's not only about the content, but also about the intention of the news source.

Finally, you should also consider the impact of the news. What are the consequences of this event, and what does it mean for your life? Does it affect your own community or your personal circumstances? Can you learn from it? Does it inspire or inform you in some way?

You can also send it to an agent. An agent is someone who finds authors and books for publishers. If they like your book, they will take it on. They will try to get a publisher interested and then will look after the business side of your contract. But again, this is a very competitive area and not easy to get into, especially for a new writer.

2. Self-publish.

This means that you will pay to have your book printed and then do all the selling and promoting yourself. This is not as difficult as it sounds, but it will cost money and take a lot of your time and energy.

## Careers advice

Careers advice has been around for a long time. Before the establishment of the careers guidance profession in the 1970s it was only available from schools, employers or further education colleges.

Careers advisers are often called counsellors or consultants and they are trained in careers guidance. This is a professional development qualification recognized across the globe.

Careers advisers are trained to understand the complexity of the career decision making process. They are knowledgeable in the use of psychometric tests and they must be able to interpret the results and provide appropriate advice.

Career guidance is available from a number of sources:

- state-funded careers guidance in schools
- charities and charitable organizations
- professional career guidance firms (you can find them listed in directories such as the one available from the British Association of Vocational Test Users (BAVT))
- voluntary organizations such as the Prince's Trust
- employment agencies
- Job Centres Plus and local authorities
- the National Careers Service

The kingfisher Wildlife photographer Charlie James is an expert on the kingfisher: a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and riversfeeding on fish. Old trees overhang the stream half shading shallow water. Soft greens mud browns and the many different yellows of sunlight are the main colours as soft as the sounds of water in the breeze.

Charlie says The bird is small but has a big character. The bird has a very hard beak, used for breaking the shells and bones of the fish it feeds on. This beak is so sharp that it can also cut through plastic fishing line left in the water. It can dive like an arrow into deep water, holding its breath for several seconds.

This bird has an interesting social life too. Male and female kingfishers nest very close to each other. The male has a special piece of fish to feed his female partner when she chooses him to be her mate. After that they remain mates for life, though they have different home bases.

The kingfisher also has special dives in air as it lands. Before it touches the water or the tree it flutters its wings for some time. It is one of the most beautiful birds in the world. When it returns to its home after a dive it makes a distinctive call.

Charlie says that the kingfisher is not just a beautiful bird but also plays a major role in the ecosystem. Because kingfishers eat so many fish, they help keep populations in balance. In many rivers, the decline of this bird shows that the river is polluted. Where there is a healthy population, we know that the water is relatively clean.

In April 1919 the British rulers in India decided to put down protests in the city of Amritsar. As people gathered in the public garden during the festival of Vaisakhi a British general ordered his soldiers to block the exits and shoot into the crowd. As well as thousands of injuries there were hundreds of deaths. The general was disciplined for his misjudgement but he continued to serve in the army, whilst many Indians were furious. The anger caused by this event contributed to growing support for Indian independence from Britain.

1. Why did the British want to put down protests in the city of Amritsar?
2. How did the general show his disregard for human life?
3. What happened after the British general had been disciplined?

The answers can be found in the passage.

1. The British wanted to put down protests in the city of Amritsar to maintain control and keep the people from becoming too radical.
2. The general showed his disregard for human life by ordering his soldiers to block the exits and shoot into the crowd, resulting in hundreds of deaths.
3. The general was disciplined for his actions, but he continued to serve in the army. This only added to the anger of many Indians who were seeking independence from Britain.

It is a curious sensation and you do feel like you are flying, especially as the scenery whizzes by.

Weisman explains that with the absence of human activity, New York would eventually be almost entirely swallowed up by nature. Birds, including the hawks that were once nearly extinct, would return to New York and would be able to nest and reproduce in the buildings. Sound the Alarm Stuart Harris reports Many of us listen to the radio when we get up in the morning and most of us also require some external means to persuade us to get out of bed. Thus we have the clock radio. But how do you pick a good one? In a recent article on the CNET website, Mike Gikas has some helpful tips: - Look for a digital alarm; an electromechanical alarm will give you a headache. - Don't buy a radio that uses a standard battery: you'll have to replace the battery yourself. An AA or AAA cell is a good choice - they are inexpensive and last a long time. - If you want a CD player or a tape player, buy a single-model stereo radio. - Look for a built-in rechargeable battery. This way you won't need to replace the batteries, and the radio will continue to work during a power outage. - Finally, remember to check the frequency range. For those who live near busy streets, the FM band has more static, but you can find fewer stationary signals in the AM band. Choose the one that best suits your needs. What to avoid: - Avoid radios with a built-in AM-FM receiver. The signals can interfere with one another, making a noisy sound. - Don't buy a clock that requires constant adjustment. Digital clocks should allow for automatic updates. - Look for a unit with an alarm volume control. This will allow you to set the radio at a comfortable volume level while still waking you up in the morning.

I HAD a most peculiar period of my life when I didn’t have any summers. 1980 was the first year I was away from home at university and since then until 1985 I was either in the Arctic, Antarctica or somewhere in the southern hemisphere during our summers, and in the other hemisphere in the northern summer.

I’ve had no winter holidays whatsoever and I’ve missed every British summer since 1980 apart from about 10 days in 1985 when I was doing some work on the Barbican Centre in London. During the last five or six months, I’ve been back in the UK more often than before because it’s a year since the new WWF [World Wide Fund for Nature] office opened and we are busy trying to move the organisation to the next stage in its evolution.

That’s taken up the best part of a year since it officially opened in September.

What I’ve found most exciting is how much we have been able to achieve so far within this new structure. I find working for a larger organisation more stimulating than running a relatively small one. There are more opportunities to get things done and you can be involved in many more diverse areas of concern.

If you look at the way the WWF is now organised, it is much more flexible and it takes a more holistic view of the environment, including the social and economic consequences of environmental activities.

Hedgehogs A hedgehog is a small mammal characterised by the sharp spines which cover its body. The hedgehogs are found in many different parts of the world none is native to either America or Australia. All species of hedgehog share the ability to roll into a tight ball when attacked so that their spines point outwards. The two types of hedgehog found in Britain are the Western Hedgehog and the Eastern Hedgehog.

Habitats and Food Hedgehogs are opportunistic feeders which means they will eat almost anything, their diet is mainly invertebrates. They also eat berries and vegetables and can be opportunist predators of small mammals, birds, amphibians and other insects. They make their homes in a variety of places.

Favourite Food – Caterpillars

Reproduction Hedgehogs are normally solitary animals but they can come together to mate between August and December. After mating, the female hedgehog creates a nest, where she will give birth to between 4 and 8 babies called hoglets. Hoglets are blind when born and feed on their mothers milk for the first 4-6 weeks.

Life Span
Hedgehogs have a lifespan of up to 7 years.

Population and Conservation
It is thought that the number of hedgehogs in the UK has decreased by about a third since 2000. The main reasons for this are habitat loss, roads, and the decrease in insect prey populations. Hedgehogs are now protected under the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981.

Before the Industrial Revolution blacksmiths enjoyed the same status as doctors and astrologers because they were the sole providers of weapons armour and farming tools.

Blacksmiths can trace their occupational history back to a time when men forged metal with the use of fire stone and hammer. They are the progenitors of the metallurgists and chemists of today.

They work with fire in a way that most humans could never imagine and have an intimate knowledge of the metallurgical world. They can see heat. When their work is red-hot they can actually watch the material transform into a plastic-like mass.

They heat it to a specific temperature to give it specific qualities. With the touch of a hand they can determine if the metal is red hot or if it is just glowing orange.

They can look at a horse shoe nail and tell you how long it takes to forge it and how much it will cost. They can take a piece of steel and by heating and cooling it many times they can create a tool that can take more punishment than a hard wood tree.

Throughout history blacksmiths have been at the center of community life. They worked in the village as a service to the rest of the people and in return the people supplied them with material to work. Photograph: John Stokes In 1700 Sir Edmund Halley embarked on an ambitious project to survey compass variations across the whole of Britain. The mathematician and astronomer, who is best known for the comet that bears his name, was determined to establish a national standard for magnetic compasses, which would allow sailors to chart their courses accurately. Halley and his team of 15 observers had travelled thousands of miles by coach, taking measurements in far-flung reaches of the country. From the coast of Cornwall to the Firth of Forth in Scotland, Halley used a specially designed iron compass, or a terrella, to measure the deviation of the compass needle from magnetic north. He was seeking true north. The results were recorded on two maps, one showing the line of true north and the other the line of magnetic north. In the two and a half centuries since Halley's death, the Earth's magnetic field has shifted substantially and his maps have long been obsolete. The pen is mightier than the psychoanalyst The study of handwriting to reveal a person’s character is gaining support If you applied for a job in some countries you would almost certainly be asked for a sample of your handwriting. And it would be the handwriting as much as anything else that would determine your suitability for the job. In an increasingly computerised world, it is remarkable that handwriting analysis remains a very real and serious profession. Graphology, as it is known, was founded by the French psychologist Frederic Rochat in 1870 and is now used by multinational corporations, the military and police forces in various parts of the world, as well as the intelligence and security services.

The United States Secret Service, for example, uses handwriting analysis as one of its investigative tools. While handwriting may provide a useful snapshot of someone’s character, many of the claims made on its behalf have been challenged. Some psychologists and psychiatrists are more sceptical, but that doesn’t seem to have done much to slow down the growth of the profession. It is used extensively for employment purposes, although the way in which it is interpreted can vary enormously.

Order now

For some companies handwriting analysis is just a supplementary aid to more formal tests and interviews. For others it may be crucial. Some of the world’s leading corporations employ handwriting analysts on a full-time basis to vet potential employees. This is not just a question of style or form, but an examination of the script itself. But what exactly does it reveal? Some companies may use it to assess things such as a person’s creativity, their ability to fit into a team, their honesty, stability and so on.

The first thing to remember about the collection is that nothing here is genuine. All the sculptures are accurate replicas cast from the originals mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. This collection is one of the most important in the world.

The Museum of Classical Archaeology focuses primarily on classical Greece and Rome, but also on the Etruscan and Pre-Roman Civilisations. This collection contains copies of sculptures from around the ancient world, including Greece, Rome, Egypt, and other regions in the ancient Mediterranean world.

The collection is divided into four main sections:

I. A Greek Section
This section contains the largest and one of the most famous group of sculptures in the Museum. It is the replica of the Parthenon frieze.

II. An Egyptian Section
This section contains copies of ancient Egyptian sculptures.

III. A Roman and Etruscan Section
This section contains copies of sculptures from Rome and Etruria, and a selection of early Christian sarcophagi from Rome.

IV. A Section of Modern Restorations
This section contains copies of sculptures from modern times, including some works of classical inspiration.

B. The Ashmolean Museum
The Ashmolean Museum, which is part of the University, was founded by Sir Thomas Bodley in 1683 and houses many of the University’s art treasures, including its famous collection of antiquities and classical sculpture.

When I had my first job as a waitress in a restaurant I soon learnt that the best way to get myself out of trouble was to smile sweetly at every possible opportunity. 'I'm so sorry' I beamed when I dropped the plate on the floor and it smashed into smithereens. 'I'm sure it was no trouble at all', I simpered as the angry customer threw bread rolls at me after I had forgotten his special request for extra toast. The customer service training I received taught me all about 'damage limitation', and it was here that I first learnt about the concept of being 'too nice'.

So, is it possible to be 'too nice'? I'm sure you've all met the kinds of people who, even though they mean well, actually drive you mad with their constant need to be helpful, their sweet, overbearing smiles and their inability to say no. And, as hard as it is to admit, we've all been there. So, if being too nice is so widely recognised, why do we still do it and how do we stop?

POWER DRESSING EVERY SUMMER the peacocks that roam free within Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire expose their magnificent trains to the critical and often disdainful gaze of the hens. They re-enact the mystery that tormented Charles Darwin to his dying day: how in this competitive world where nature as Tennyson said - is red in tooth and claw could birds have evolved such an obvious extravagance?

Charles Darwin

Darwin had two things to say about the peacock's tail. First, he saw the tail as an elaborate waste of energy; a luxury, a non-essential appendage that would do no more than make the peacock a slow and easy target for predators. And, second, he saw it as a weapon, a show of threat. Its size and flamboyance would send a clear signal to a rival that the male holding this train was a fierce competitor.

But then a second problem arose. How did the peacock use its tail? Darwin could see the male flaunting his plumage to the females, as the females were known to be quite partial to a large train. But how did he use it against other males? Darwin was not the first to witness peacocks engaging in what was then known as ‘pea-cock-ing’, and he was able to offer an explanation: the train, which appears so large and so unwieldy, is in fact remarkably nimble, allowing the bird to move the feathers about with startling rapidity.

NATURAL TALENTS In the mere seven million years since we humans separated from chimpanzees we haven’t had time to develop any differences: genetically we’re still more than 98 per cent identical to chimps. On this grand evolutionary scale whatever it is that separates humans from animals is a very recent development. So in this gallery we take a look at those talents that animals share with humans and which have been finely honed over millions of years.

1. SPRINGING INTO ACTION
Many animals can jump and bound with ease, taking advantage of the way their bodies bend and compress to produce powerful and controlled propulsion. Humans excel at this thanks to our opposable thumbs and perfect musculature, but we’re not alone: kangaroos can jump as high as 10 metres and deer are also natural jumpers.

2. NIGHT-TIME NAVIGATION
There are a few species of animal able to navigate their way around at night, and humans are no exception. Our eyes contain the light-sensitive photoreceptor rods that detect low levels of light, especially blue wavelengths, and adapt to darkness to help us see in the dark. Many animals, however, such as moths and certain species of bird, have similar adaptations.

3. EXPLORING WITH SENSES
Animals, like humans, have to rely on the data available to them through their senses in order to make their way through the world. Humans hear well across a wide frequency range with our ears. But for detecting vibrations and movement, we’re not alone; elephants have excellent hearing, while dolphins can detect vibrations through the water.

Chewing gum culture It’s fashionable classless and Americans chew 12 million sticks of it a day. Discover how an ancient custom became big business. Chewing gum contains fewer than ten calories per stick but it is classified as a food and must therefore conform to the standards of the American Food and Drug Administration. If you ask somebody what he does for a living and he says he makes chewing gum, you’re likely to think of a small, family-run business and the sound of chewing gum being wrapped in cellophane. But today’s chewing gum is big business, a $10 billion-a-year industry with 11,000 different products ranging from Wrigley’s Juicy Fruit to Altoids mints. The first chewing gum factory in the world was built by Thomas Adams in New York in 1871. Adams was a photography pioneer, but found that his stock of gum base, a by-product of the bituminous coal business, was more useful than his camera-produced images. In 1871, Adams introduced the first flavored chewing gum in the US, and soon he was selling 300,000 sticks a day. Today his company, the Adams Gum Company, is one of the biggest in the industry, and the name “Wrigley’s” almost as synonymous with chewing gum as Kleenex is with tissues.

But transition means going surely and sweetly from somewhere present to somewhere future. Unless that is it is newspapers’ ‘transition’ to the online world an uncertain and highly uncomfortable process – because frankly it may not be a process at all. We will not, as a species, read print newspapers, or magazines, for much longer, and the sooner the realisation hits home the better. We will print them, of course – for a dwindling and ageing audience, in ever-decreasing numbers – but the essence of the medium has gone and isn’t coming back. For a start, we are too impatient, and too connected to the news wires, for the lag time of 24 hours (at least) between gathering and being gathered up. We are too attached to our iPods for not being able to carry vast libraries. We are too addicted to online crosswords for no longer being able to reach across a page to scratch numbers into a paper square. We are too wedded to the idea of free speech and interactive discussion in comments columns and forums. There’s a world out there, full of digital wonder. Acupuncture works to balance the body’s vital energies or qi. This energy flows through the body along pathways called meridians. While not all supermarkets have them, those that do will often have a basket of fruit in the middle of the aisle - one that is filled with tempting, ripe fruit. A study of British supermarket giant Tesco found that 47 per cent of customers were drawn to buy something - often something unplanned - at the 'impulse' stand. B. The wall of products The rows and rows of identical products stacked on high shelves are actually designed to create the illusion of space within the store. Three theories about sleep People spend about one-third of their lives asleep. It seems certain therefore that sleep has a vital function. However what that function might be is still in debate. Scientists are far from being in agreement about precisely why so much of our precious time is given over to sleep. Three popular theories are presented here but all remain hypotheses that are not fully established.

The Restoration theory Sleep restores the body’s energy levels. During sleep, metabolism slows and energy usage falls. This theory suggests that sleep allows the body to rest and recuperate in much the same way that it conserves energy by slowing metabolism during hibernation.

One of the most compelling pieces of evidence in support of the restoration theory is the fact that physical and mental activities increase sleep need. Athletes, for example, tend to sleep for longer periods of time and experience greater feelings of fatigue if they are deprived of sleep. Similarly, a student who has crammed for exams may feel more need for rest. Research has shown that deep stages of sleep (N3) increase significantly when subjects are deprived of sleep, indicating that the body is striving to meet increased energy demands during these periods of rest.

One weakness of the restoration theory is that not all energy conservation during sleep is convincing evidence for this explanation. It is true that during sleep body temperature declines and oxygen consumption falls but this also occurs when subjects are in a waking, resting state. Furthermore, the fact that physical and mental activity can raise sleep needs is not strong evidence that sleep functions to restore energy. For instance, eating does not need sleep to restore our energy. Instead, it directly provides us with energy.

It was through the encouragement of my father that I started to write. I remember my earliest efforts at a young age of five years. This, in those days, was quite remarkable given the amount of effort needed to keep a quill pen nib sharp and ink flowing.

My first piece of published writing was a small poem that featured in The Govan Press in Scotland. In those days, newspapers came out every few days, rather than every few hours. My second piece, written when I was eight years old, was a short story published in The Courier in Dundee. It featured the local zoo and its residents.

I remember how much effort it took to write by hand and how careful I had to be. Any mistake and the only way to correct it was to scratch it out and start again. His face is used to advertise products with intellectual connotations from computers to encyclopaedias. And he’s up there with Darwin and Newton as a famous British cultural icon, alongside Shakespeare and Dickens.

The man who had a huge impact on our understanding of the physical world might have had trouble getting a job in a research university today. Many biologists do not believe in evolution, nor do they understand quantum physics.

What’s more, universities are often more interested in how many citations a scientist receives and how many students they can attract than in the intellectual calibre of the scientist. Einstein, who worked mainly in his spare time and with no grant for most of his career, could not get a job in a British research university today.

I was a member of a committee set up to select candidates for the professorship of physics at the University of Cambridge. One of the major criteria was the number of papers a candidate had published. How many grants they had received as a post-doctoral fellow was also crucial, even though the candidate had a permanent job at the time of application. Einstein would not have come anywhere near the top, and it is questionable if he would have made the final shortlist.

Amateur Astronomy Many things have changed in astronomy over the past half-century. Until about 30 years ago there was a great shortage of charts and catalogues. Telescopic equipment was limited and there were few books on practical astronomy. Today the range of off-the-shelf telescopes and equipment covers almost everything one could need. There are literally hundreds of books available to the amateur astronomer, from simple books on the constellations through to the most complex books on variable stars, galaxies, and so forth. Even magazines and newsletters abound.

Today the most popular observing activity is photographing the night sky. With the advent of the digital camera, it is relatively simple and inexpensive. A digital camera and telescope can be had for under $1000 (1000 euros, pounds etc). There are also some astronomical photography magazines, which have a number of articles, tutorials, and reviews of equipment. You can learn a great deal about the night sky and photography at the same time.

Art In modern times - more and more over the course of the last two hundred years - we have come to speak as though every artist had to rebel against the art of his contemporaries. Art is praised in terms of being unique revolutionary shocking even. We feel good about admiring the artist whose work no one appreciated a hundred years ago. The history of our era of modern art has been the history of the artist as a self-conscious rebel against convention; as a daring innovator with a mission to change the world. Art in our time has come to symbolize our most rebellious impulses as a society. We celebrate art as an expression of our desire to be different and to shock people, to say to others "we are different, we are wild, we won't be told what to do".

However, art has been used for a very long time in a far more conventional manner. It has generally served the purpose of portraying some kind of objective reality. In the great tradition of portraiture and historical painting, artists have always been asked to record the events, the people, and the places of their times. The most admired artists throughout history were not rebels but rather those who had mastered techniques and disciplines. They were seen as great craftsmen, whose skills were used to beautify our environment and to record our experiences and memories in a lasting form.

Modern artists - like Picasso - who rebelled against convention were in fact few in number. The world would be a poorer place if these artists had not produced their iconoclastic works which have been so loved and admired. Fashion Fashion is often seen as a modern phenomenon entirely dependent upon nineteenth- and twentieth-century capitalism for its development. Most historians of fashion are at pains to point out though that fashion at least in the sense of style and design has a very long history. They often take the rise of the market and mercantile trade in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries as their starting point. They have good reason to do so: from the end of the sixteenth century onwards, there are more detailed descriptions of clothing than ever before, and these descriptions contain explicit comparisons and evaluations of various styles and modes of dressing, and it is in this sense that we can begin to talk about 'fashions'.

The earliest fashion commentaries are to be found in courtly writings, especially those emanating from French courts. Some commentaries of this period also mention regional differences in dress - the first of many instances of 'national dress' which in the eighteenth century begin to take on much greater importance. In the second half of the seventeenth century, the term 'fashion' itself comes into use in reference to clothing, and by the eighteenth century it is common.

### 'Fashioning'

Fashioning, however, is more than a simple economic or political phenomenon; for fashion (if we may use this term to encompass style, dress, clothes) is a social practice that enables the creation of individual and social identities. The 'fashioning' of an identity involves not only decisions about clothing and appearance but also about status, gender, age, health, body shape and form. The body as 'living' material is fashioned in various ways that express aspects of the individual and social experience. Metals It may have been a wish for self-adornment that aroused the interest of Stone Age people in metals. Sitting by the side of a river waiting for a fish to come within a spears throw or just idling away a moment one of our early ancestors might have happened upon a shiny yellow pebble and plucked it off the river bed. Such glimpses of a new kind of material would have caused him to think. He would pick it up, examine it and then perhaps make a hole in the stone to hang on a string as a decorative charm. He might have been disappointed with this kind of jewel but he did not give up so easily. There was a sense of new discovery that could not be so easily dismissed.

Metals are a unique subset of substances on the face of the earth. These are substances that are hard, shiny, easily polished and capable of reflecting a clear image. Most of the metals are highly conductive to heat and electricity. They are so well known because they glitter and are visible at a distance. Our ancestors might have started to search for more such glittering stones in the rivers, on the hills and in the rocks but they probably found little apart from the shiny pebbles that had already come their way.

The discovery of fire would have given them the first means of working with metals. The heat caused by fire would be necessary for turning pebbles into tools but it was still a long way from this first step to the fashioning of useful metal objects. After much trial and error our Stone Age ancestors would have learned that the only way to produce the necessary heat for this purpose is by forging the stone in an intense flame.

Enough Sleep? Tiredness it is often claimed has become the modern condition. As the richer busier countries have grown so sleeplessness and anxiety have also grown in the popular psyche. Research in the USA has found 40 million Americans to be chronically affected and some recent best-selling novels in Britain have featured insomniacs as protagonists or sleep-research laboratories as their settings.

So why do so many people feel they aren’t getting enough sleep? One view is that we should no longer have problems sleeping because, as a species, human beings have been doing it since time immemorial. Surely evolution must have equipped us to sleep well enough to avoid problems? It’s also important to understand that sleeplessness is a complex and multi-causal phenomenon, the causes of which will be considered below.

In the last few years of the 20th century researchers have also argued that insomnia has become a major health problem for an increasingly urbanized world. According to these studies people in the west are working harder and sleeping less. There is a popular belief that modern technology and the 24-hour society have disrupted the circadian rhythm, which controls sleep and waking.

Modern technology has many advantages but there are drawbacks including the erosion of the importance of a good night’s rest. Some people believe that we should all be able to adapt to a world in which 24-hour TV and nighttime working are commonplace and that there should be less focus on what is a natural part of human life.

THE WELL I had read somewhere that from a sufficiently deep hole one could see the stars if the day were clear. I had persuaded you to help me with my scheme; you watched eyes wide fist to mouth as I winched up the well bucket steadied it on the wall and then climbed in. A momentary thrill, then I’d have to climb back out. There was no need to reassure you that I would call up for help if I started to feel claustrophobic. You’re the practical one and even if we’d been at loggerheads all day I’d not have wanted to disappoint you. It’s not that it was all over so much as the beginning of a journey towards a very specific destination. I lowered myself, claustrophobia’s chill already creeping at my neck and inching through my spine but I kept going, the darkness surrounding me, a world of possibilities.

—–

EarthBounder

Joyce’s language here speaks volumes in just a few short sentences.  The “motionless hall” and the “momentary qualm of ownership” both speak to an unoccupied house, a house unlived in or uncared for. Heritage The true meaning and significance of heritage is that it gives people and communities a genuine sense of connection with the past. Obviously we feel connected to our personal heritage usually we know who and what our grandparents were and we will have heard stories about how they lived. We also have a deeper connection to the communities we grew up in, and have some knowledge of their history, their landmarks and events that have taken place in these communities. These connections are our heritage as they are all related to where we come from and the values that have been passed down to us from previous generations. Heritage plays a huge role in preserving our cultural identities, and without our heritage we would lose some of the most important traditions, values and experiences that have made us who we are today.  This is why it is vital to ensure that heritage is celebrated, preserved and protected. Othello The transfer to London from Stratford of an exceptional production of Shakespeare’s play Othello allows me to make amends for an unfair review that I wrote when the show opened last spring. Back then I complained that Ray Fearon was too young to play the title role and I was guilty of running down his acting. 

My criticism was based on my belief that only a 60-year-old could carry off a performance in the same mould as Olivier's or Guinness's. Now, having watched Fearon's performance, I can see that maturity and stagecraft aren't the only things that count. What counts above all is the inner life of the character. Fearon has plenty of that. With a commanding, intelligent presence, he exudes the dignity and pride of an African general who has risen to high office in a racist white society.

He also has the physical strength and authority needed to make it clear to us how threatening he is to the Venetian oligarchs. They are alarmed that a black man should be entrusted with command of a ship and, ultimately, the city. The fact that the audience finds him so attractive only adds to their alarm. And yet there is something of the young man about him – he's still learning, making mistakes, and capable of falling in love.

He gives the part a powerful performance, showing us Othello’s nobility and sensitivity, and the desperation of a proud man whose life has become one long nightmare. He also shows us that, while Iago’s poison has destroyed the love between Othello and Desdemona, Othello’s love for her remains undimmed

Observing Lions In the popular imagination lions hunting for food present a marvel of group choreography: in the dying light of sunset a band of stealthy cats springs forth from the shadows like trained assassins and surrounds its unsuspecting prey. The lions seem to be archetypal social animals rising above petty dissension to work together towards a common goal - in this case their next meal. But in reality such well-rehearsed cooperative efforts are exceedingly rare. As often as not, one lion does the stalking, one makes the kill, and the rest sit around and wait their turn to eat. Occasionally two lions may stalk a single animal, but even in these cases their cooperation consists more of toleration than coordination. Of the three methods of stalking used by lions, the most common is the "creeping stalk" in which the lion approaches its prey as slowly and subtly as possible. The lion then moves very slowly into position for a long distance shot. This technique requires a great deal of patience and skill, and is rarely accompanied by the dramatic displays of stealth and group choreography that captivate the popular imagination. The two remaining methods of stalking - the "walking stalk" and the "running stalk" - are both more straightforward than the creeping stalk, but less effective at bringing the lion and its prey into direct contact. The walking stalk, in which the lion gets close to the prey by moving across its line of sight and then taking a long shot, was probably more common in the past when lion numbers were much higher and many of the large animals that lions hunt were more plentiful than they are today. Garbage in garbage out Charging families for each bag of rubbish they produce seems environmentally sound and economically sensible. It may not be. Some rituals of modern domestic living vary little throughout the developed world. One such is the municipal refuse collection: at regular intervals rubbish bags or the contents of rubbish bins disappear into the bowels of a special lorry and are carried away to the local tip. This is a good thing, of course; it eliminates mounds of rotting detritus, eliminates rats, stops people throwing unwanted items into nearby rivers or woods, and so on. What if we were to pay for this service directly? I do not mean some kind of tax on houses, shops or cars, but charging families for each bag of rubbish they produce: pay by weight, maybe, or by volume. This is already happening in some cities in Japan and America, and there is a move afoot in the UK, for example, to introduce such charges. The advantages are clear enough. We would soon come to regard rubbish with much greater care, for we would be paying for the privilege of its disposal. If the price is right, then we would reuse things more and recycle them more too; both are good for the environment. Even a small change in behaviour can make a big difference. If a family uses only three bags a week instead of five, that means a lot less waste. At the same time we could get the prices right. Then a stifling quiet settled on the field. My heart pounded. I stared as hundreds of heads craned in my direction. I couldn’t see any goats. The people were watching me.

(P. 55, Easter in the Caribbean.)

The disjointedness of sentence structure mirrors the overwhelming nature of the scene.

0ral History The growing trend for historians to rely on oral evidence is not without its problems. It is naive to suppose that someone’s testimony represents a pure distillation of past experience for in an interview each party is affected by the other. Memories are selective and, especially where a controversial or sensational event is being discussed, people can lie, embellish the truth or forget important details. For a reliable account, several testimonies may need to be compared with documentary sources. However, in the case of many historical events, especially from the 19th century and earlier, such comparisons are impossible because few documentary sources exist. If this is the case, then the historian has a choice between accepting one person’s testimony over another, and risking inaccuracy, or rejecting all oral evidence altogether and risking the loss of important information. The importance of such testimony is shown in the case of the massacre of thousands of Maoris during the New Zealand Wars of the 1860s. The number of Maoris killed at the Battle of Orakau alone is uncertain, and depends on oral history and written accounts. Both sources reveal conflict and controversy, and it is in these areas that oral history can illuminate an otherwise silent past. It is also in these areas that historians need to be most careful. In the case of the Orakau massacre, for example, the number of dead varies between ten and 200, depending on whose oral evidence is being taken. Vervet monkeys Cheney and Seyfarth describe how one day the dominant male in the group of vervet monkeys they were studying noticed a strange male hanging around in a neighbouring grove of trees. The stranger’s intentions were quite obvious: he was sizing up the group in order to join it. The dominant male took charge. He leapt down from the highest branches of a nearby tree and began to make threatening displays. His hair was standing on end, his eyes wide open, and he screamed and shouted with his head thrown back and his hands on his hips.

Seyfarth and Cheney report that the stranger did not stand a chance. This alpha vervet male ‘…bared his teeth, clenched them, and produced a high-pitched scream. He charged forward, and hit the intruder three times on the rump, then ran a few meters away and turned to look back as if to say, “I’ll be waiting…”’ The message was unmistakable. “Welcome to the group. We will make sure you behave according to our rules, and if you don’t you’ll be out of here like a shot.” This was, of ‘…a classic case of a challenge ritual.’

AESTHETICS By one of the ironic perversities that often attend the course of affairs the existence of the works of art upon which formation of aesthetic theory depends has become an obstruction to theory about them. For one reason: these works are products that exist externally and physically. They are not ideas or images. They are perceptible and therefore palpable. They are physical objects, and for that matter physical objects that were once made by human beings, which is a characteristic they do not share with the ideas or the images. It is this perceptible and palpable quality which makes it so difficult for a man to be at all certain about the work in the sense that one is usually certain about one's thoughts, feelings, or ideas.

Aesthetic theory has thus encountered a very odd problem that is not encountered in other fields. On the one hand, a piece of music, for example, as a piece of music is a product which has both been made by a man and exists objectively, but on the other hand it has an existence which, by virtue of being a product, tends to disappear and vanish into the air; and it does this just as it tends to make us aware, or should make us aware, of the fact that all the while we were listening to it, it was objectively there in front of us. It is precisely this fact that can so easily confound a listener's attitude toward the piece of music as a product, a fact to which many a composition has succumbed, for example the symphony, as a work of art and as a product at the same time. The only thing that is certain about it from the moment it begins, is that it will end.

Work Theodore Zeldin looks at how our working life could change. Are you as respected and appreciated as you deserve? Success in a career is no longer enough. Every profession is complaining that it is not properly valued or understood and even among individuals who have won eminence there is often bitterness behind the fame. This is a sign that there may be a general malaise in society because there is a contradiction between the high expectations that people now have of success and the difficulty of achieving it. There is also the fact that we feel less confident when we are older about how successful we have been. This is the time to ask ourselves whether there is any way to renew the sense of success that is fundamental to our well-being. To be respected and appreciated is to have earned recognition for something one has done. It is not just the fact of being rewarded that is important - it is the ability to see that reward in a favourable light, to take pleasure in a success that is felt to be deserved. There is still considerable room for improvement in our approach to rewarding work. The way we regard success in the workplace has become less important than the fact that it has happened. Success has lost part of its fascination for us because we have become over-preoccupied with the process of achieving it. The sense of the present has been sacrificed for an obsession with the future. A better balance has to be re-established between the past and the future. This means being more aware of the reasons for our past successes. This will give us a better sense of the nature of those successes and enable us to relate them better to our current situation. There should be more opportunities for people to reflect and take time to review what they have done and achieved.

Every Picture Tells a Story Adapting novels for film almost always involves a process of reduction condensation and deletion. This can be very frustrating for the writer but also illuminating. Working on a script I was struck by how much of the dialogue and narrative description in a given scene in the novel I could dispense with while still getting across the same point. I began to think of the film as an elitist medium and of myself as an elitist.

The film as a form is inherently elitist; you have to possess a certain level of cultural knowledge or acuity to understand it as it is meant to be understood. The novelist has the space to expand on ideas; the screenwriter does not. The film is all about the image. Images need to be seen in order for the idea to be realised fully. So, the film viewer must know something; he or she must have a certain vocabulary to be able to comprehend and analyse the images.

A simple example. A character in the novel might say: “I will never be able to forgive him;” this phrase can be reduced to a single image: A character with an expression of profound disgust looking at an image of the character he or she cannot forgive. And that image speaks volumes. The image, like all images in a film, is intended to convey meaning.

This realisation can lead to a very rewarding process of reduction and clarification for the screenwriter, who has to get down to the most basic level of the story and strip it bare. If the novel has, for example, twenty pages of characterisation or back-story, the screenwriter has to ask: What do we need to know about this character in order to understand the story as it unfolds on screen?

The Heat is On We’ve all heard of global warming but just how much warmer will the earth get and how will it affect our lives? Almost everyone has some idea of what global warming is all about but no one is quite sure about its consequences. A warmer climate is likely to mean changes to the weather in all parts of the world. For example, there will be changes in the frequency and intensity of storms in some areas, droughts and floods in others, and a gradual melting of polar ice caps. The climate will be changing in other ways too. More rainfall may cause rising sea levels and lead to loss of farmland and homes. Scientists predict that global warming may affect agriculture and food production. It could mean that food has to be imported from other countries which, in turn, will drive up the cost of food in our local shops. Increased humidity will make us feel hotter, and more humidity means more mosquitoes. Global warming could even be responsible for the spread of tropical diseases into countries where they have never been seen before. The warmer temperatures will also have a knock-on effect on other aspects of our lives. For example, the production of alcoholic drinks may decrease as it relies on cold temperatures for fermentation. It’s difficult to think of a situation where global warming will be welcomed with open arms. The truth is, as the earth heats up, we will all feel the effects, and it will be up to us to make changes to our lifestyle in order to make the most of a challenging future. This is partly because of his extraordinary perseverance: he led two major expeditions to the Antarctic at the beginning of the 20th century, coming close to success on his third, before the Endurance was crushed in the ice in 1915. Shackleton's leadership is celebrated in the management literature as a series of well-handled crises which he dealt with calmly, without losing sight of his ultimate goal. Music - The Challenge Ahead Technological advances continue to transform our lives at work at home and in our leisure activities. Susan Hallam discusses their impact on music in Britain. In the latter part of the 20th century we saw a rapid increase in the opportunities available for listening to music through radio TV records tapes CDs videos and a rapidly developing range of multi-media techniques. The range of people able to access music has widened. It is not just the educated and wealthy who can enjoy music today. Music has become a mass phenomenon and music education has become accessible to all, for example through the national curriculum. Accessibility is a double-edged sword, though. On the one hand, it is a tremendous benefit that more people have access to the riches of the past, and that today's music is more diverse than ever. On the other hand, there is a danger that a homogenised culture might emerge and that some of the variety of musical experience might be eroded, with everyone listening to the same kind of music.

I think that the key issue is how to encourage a lifelong love for music in people of all ages and that this has to be done in an individual way. We should not expect everyone to love the same kind of music or indeed the same kind of approach to music. The challenge is to find ways in which individuals can be guided to music that will be personally rewarding and enriching. For children and young people, this should mean providing a range of opportunities for them to engage in music - opportunities that allow them to try out different genres and styles.

For adults, it means providing ways in which they can continue to explore and develop their musical experience, whether this is by listening to music, learning to play instruments, or even creating new music themselves. This is a big challenge

Holiday reading Summer promises us two of life’s great joys: escaping home and reading books - joys that are of course intimately connected. Books may help us to feel more at home in the world at large. We can relate our experiences to those described in great books written long ago or in distant lands because there are fewer human types than there are people. As one of the great explorers put it, 'The world is a book and those who do not travel read only one page.' To read and to travel may be the two greatest joys in life because they allow us to become others and experience new worlds. While you holiday away, we hope you will find a few of these great books to take with you.

Photography When a photographer takes a photograph he or she makes a selection of visual information that is determined by his or her technical and aesthetic skills personal views and experience together with a set of social and cultural norms. The photographer then edits this information to create a finished photograph that is communicative and expressive and that has a significant social and cultural impact. Photographers use a camera.

The first cameras were invented in China, they were wood and bamboo vessels used from the 5th century BC. In ancient Greece, camera obscura, the precursor of the photographic camera, was employed as a mechanical device for producing pictures. In 1826, Joseph Nicéphore Niépce made the first recorded photograph on a pewter plate. In 1827, the first camera with a lens, the diorama, was invented by Louis Daguerre. In 1839, the first photograph was made by George Eastman, with the invention of roll film. By the 1900s, cameras were miniaturized and cheap to produce.

The digital camera came about with the digital revolution and is now the most popular type of camera. The digital camera replaces the photographic film in the analog camera with digital capture by a CCD sensor. Photographers use different types of cameras and lenses to capture different types of images depending on their intention. Some photographers, for instance, focus on artistic photography or photojournalism, or they may focus on a subject, like landscape photography.

The main techniques of photography include lighting, depth of field, composition, and framing

Family Business ‘Look here it’s no good!’ said my Dad. We were in the car on the way back to London. My father with my brother Maurice in tow had just collected me and my trunk from the posh girls’ school I attended. I was tired and happy to be leaving. The school had been too academic; far too cerebral, I had felt. I preferred practical things, the sort of work Mum did. She designed houses. So as the conversation in the car continued, I shared my thoughts with them. The topic turned to what Mum did and Dad asked me what building meant to me. I said that I thought buildings were like clothes, they covered your body, or in this case, your land and made it safe and pleasant. Dad and Maurice agreed and we moved on. A few weeks later Dad told us that he’d bought a derelict house and we would be renovating it. Mum could design it and we, all of us could help fix it up. We were so excited! We’d become a family team, just like Mum and Dad, who ran their own business, designing clothes for a living.

A Family Business, Just like Theirs

Vancouver In the last ten years or so hundreds of thousands of people from all over the world have taken up residence in Vancouver in western Canada. To relax in the evening residents stroll down the city streets and if you join them you are likely to overhear a different language at almost every other step. English speaking people can also feel like strangers in a foreign country because in recent years people who speak English as their first language have become a minority in the city. A similar situation can be found in New York City where a large number of people speak Chinese, Korean or Spanish at home, so when you visit the city, you don’t just find yourself hearing another language – it’s like walking around in a different country!

Both of these cities and many others around the world have large numbers of people who are not just foreigners, but foreigners who are here to stay. The city of New York has seen a 10% increase in its population since 2000 which has been helped a lot by the arrival of immigrants. Vancouver and New York are similar to other cities in the world where immigrants are arriving in large numbers to find work and a better life, and to make a contribution to their new cities. However, their arrival can also lead to problems like overcrowded schools and hospitals, and these problems need to be addressed so that the cities can continue to grow in the right way.

In Vancouver, the increase in population has been caused by a number of different things. MUSIC AND THEATRE Up until quite recently I would have said that opera is first and foremost theatre. Not any more. After a brief spell working at u national opera house I learned that opera is in fact only secondly theatre. The music comes first. That’s as it should be of course. Now when I think of opera as a sort of theatre, it’s as a visual art form. In opera, music comes first, then comes the voice, then the story. The voice has the job of carrying the story. It’s the voice that makes an opera. What is important is to create a story around music, so the story is driven by the music. In opera, voice is character, music is emotion and orchestra is environment. The voice, because of its special ability to express emotion through music, is also the most powerful medium of communication. It can say and do things that no other art form can do so convincingly. And it is, for this reason, the reason to watch opera. The visuals, the stage settings, the costumes, all play their part in setting up the atmosphere but they are not there for the sake of the story or the character. They are there to enhance the music – music that is about to be infused with emotion and character through the singer. Opera as theatre is therefore only part of the experience. Music and character will get you 80% of the way there. The other 20% comes from what you see. Now all this has led me to an interesting conclusion. BROADCASTING: The Social Shaping of a Technology 'Broadcasting' originally meant sowing seeds broadly by hand. It is in other words not only an agricultural metaphor it is also one of optimistic modernism. It is about planned growth in the widest possible circles the production if the conditions are right of a rich harvest. The early television and radio pioneers were inspired by this idea of spreading the word.

It all started with Marconi in the late 19th century. He wanted to make people talk across the oceans. This was to be a miracle in technology and a means of peace. At that time there were no broadcasts - Marconi was sending telegrams. But in 1906 David Sarnoff - a young man from the Yiddish ghetto on the Lower East Side in New York - decided that radio should be a universal means of communication.

The first radio broadcasters were radio amateurs. They were inventors, engineers and experimenters who spent much of their time on the air, talking about the weather and local news. In the early 1920s, some of these broadcasters began to make more professional use of the medium. They started to use the new invention, the microphone and the new discovery, the commercial advertisement.

The early American broadcasting pioneers - Patterson, Ducrow, and Nye - were people of vision. They saw the potential of radio as an instrument for good and a means of mass communication. They helped spread the word of the industrial revolution across the prairies.
