Writing Reviews Frank Kermode examines the craft of review-writing from a practitioner’s point of view. Most reviews are written and circulated under conditions which ensure that they have a very short active life. They are read by the author, or his friends, who immediately respond; by people of the author’s profession who may react at once to some of the judgments, some of the time. Their impact on the writer, if they have one, is invariably transient. Of course this does not mean that the reviews are of no value to anybody.

It goes without saying that there is very little money in writing reviews, especially on the scale with which this particular subject is likely to be discussed here, which is the scale at which I usually write them. Writing is, as it were, a labour of love. It is also an occasional solicitation of loathe, but love predominates. And since it is a labour of love one wants the thing to be good, or at least not bad, though how can it be bad if the reviewer has to accept the book before he looks at it? He must not be a critical consumer, a consumer who selects the book on general principles and then offers his considered opinion of it: he is, rather, what some critics call a professional reader, someone who has to find something in the book which he can, in some way, talk about—not necessarily praise, or condemn, but talk about.

Citizen Kane When the film Citizen Kane finally appeared in 1941 despite the brouhaha that attended its release - delayed because of distributor’s fears of the harm William Randolph Hearst its alleged subject might do to them - and largely ecstatic reviews it was not a commercial success. It was television that brought it back to the public consciousness. But from the start, it was acclaimed as a cinematic masterpiece.

Citizen Kane was the final result of a screenplay workshop conducted by Orson Welles under the auspices of RKO, where he was employed, along with Herman J. Mankiewicz. The film was shot in a few weeks, on a relatively meager budget. It was also the first feature film Welles both starred in and directed, and though he did not write the script, he helped shape it.

The film’s non-linear narrative unfolds in flashbacks, employing a large ensemble cast of characters that help tell the story of the newsman Charles Foster Kane and the nature of his famous last word, “Rosebud”. Citizen Kane uses the device of newsreel footage, and dramatic readings of Kane’s fictional newspaper headlines to transition between scenes, and Welles’ innovative use of visual and aural techniques in creating the narrative were both inventive and influential.

Among these was the long take, a precursor of the single-shot scene that has become such a staple of the movies. The movie is now considered a groundbreaking work of art, and was placed at number one on the American Film Institute’s lists of the 100 greatest American films in 1997 and the 100 greatest films in American cinema

England’s breakfast revolution The importance of a good breakfast is beyond dispute according to health experts but in historical terms breakfast is a relatively new arrival in England with descriptions of breakfast seldom featuring in medieval literature. 

The English breakfast emerged in the 18th century with a newfound appetite for ‘eating’ and it became popular to offer a generous breakfast to visitors or guests which often included eggs, bacon, grilled kidneys, sausages, mushrooms, toast and marmalade. However, despite the wide range of food available, in many instances it was more of a statement of social status and wealth, rather than a hearty meal designed to fuel the day ahead.

Therefore, it was the Victorian period that saw the most rapid growth of the breakfast as we now know it. The expansion of the railway and the booming economy meant that there was a huge demand for hotels and restaurants that could offer an enticing breakfast menu, and this led to the advent of the all-day breakfast menu. One of the more famous examples is The Breakfast Club in London, which has now inspired numerous imitations around the world.

However, it is not just hotels and restaurants that have benefited from the English breakfast, as the British breakfast has also influenced other countries around the world. As the United Kingdom expanded its empire during the 19th century, they took their breakfast habits with them, and countries such as India, Australia, and Canada now have their own version of the English breakfast. The English breakfast is a symbol of home and comfort, with its familiar ingredients and tastes, and its enduring popularity means that it will continue
